edited the citation entry to accurately reflect which entry was cited in the Glossary of Archival and Records Terminology
revision.text:
The '''archival bond''' is a concept in [[archival theory]] referring to the relationship that each archival record has with the other records produced as part of the same transaction or activity and located within the same grouping. These bonds are a core component of each individual record and are necessary for transforming a document into a record, as a document will only acquire meaning (and become a record) through its interrelationships with other records.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Duranti|first=Luciana|title=The Archival Bond|journal=Archives and Museum Informatics|year=1997|volume=11|pages=213–218}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://www2.archivists.org/glossary/terms/a/archival-bond|title=A Glossary of Archival and Records Terminology, Entry for Archival Bond|last=Pearce-Moses|first=Richard|publisher=Society of American Archivists|year=2012|isbn=|location=|pages=|accessdate=11 July 2017}}</ref>
==Description==
The concept of the archival bond is primarily associated with the work of [[Luciana Duranti]], who first proposed the concept, along with [[Heather MacNeil]], as part of research into the integrity of electronic records.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Duranti|first=Luciana|author2=Heather MacNeil|title=The Protection of the Integrity of Electronic Records|journal=Archivaria|year=1996|volume=42|pages=46–67}}</ref> The concept of the archival bond emerges from the fact that electronic records are not physically arranged like traditional records. For traditional, analog records, their bond is implicit in their arrangement. But for electronic records, this bond must be made explicit due to the lack of a single sequential order of records in a digital environment.
The archival bond was one of the core concepts of the subsequent International Research on Permanent Authentic Records in Electronic Systems (InterPARES) project<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Research on Permanent Authentic Records in Electronic Systems |url=http://www.interpares.org/ |accessdate=19 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130103050624/http://www.interpares.org/ |archivedate=3 January 2013 }}</ref> and can be found in the InterPARES glossary.<ref>{{cite web|title=The InterPARES Glossary |url=http://www.interpares.org/documents/InterPARES%20Glossary%202002-1.pdf |accessdate=19 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023647/http://www.interpares.org/documents/InterPARES%20Glossary%202002-1.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 }}</ref>
As Duranti notes, the archival bond is not to be confused with the broader term "context" as context exists independent of a record while "the archival bond is an essential part of the record, which would not exist without it."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Duranti|title=The Archival Bond|pages=217}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Archival science]] [[Category:Information science]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Ashrita Furman | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = AshritaSettingBat-BalancingRecord.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = Furman in [[San Francisco]] setting a record for the fastest mile balancing a baseball bat. | birth_name = Keith Furman | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1954|09|16}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], New York | disappeared_date = <!-- {{Disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Health food store manager | years_active = since 1979 | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = [[New York City]] | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|m=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = <!-- unmarried life partner; use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> }} '''Ashrita Furman''' (born '''Keith Furman''', September 16, 1954) is a ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' record-breaker. As of 2017, Furman has set more than 600 official Guinness Records and currently holds 226 records. His most recent record is 26 watermelons sliced on his stomach in one minute<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/contact/record-enquiry|title=Record enquiry|work=Guinness World Records|access-date=2017-10-20|language=en-GB}}</ref> thus holding the record for the most Guinness world records.<ref name="GBR-2015" /> He has been breaking records since 1979.<ref name="GBR-2015" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/queens/2009/04/15/2009-04-15_100th_simultaneous_guinness_world_record_for_ashrita_furman_for_mass_poetry_reci.html |title=New York News, Local Video, Traffic, Weather, NY City Schools and Photos – Homepage |publisher=[[NY Daily News]] |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
==Life and records==
===Early life=== Furman was born in 1954 in [[Brooklyn, New York]]. He was fascinated with the ''Guinness Book of World Records'' as a child but never thought he could ever break a record, since he was very nonathletic.<ref name="sc" />
That all changed when, as a teenager, he became interested in [[spirituality]] and in 1970 became a devout follower of the spiritual leader [[Sri Chinmoy]].<ref name="Kilgannon" />
Sri Chinmoy inspired Furman to participate in a 24-hour bicycle race in [[New York City]]'s [[Central Park]] in 1978. With only two weeks' training, Furman tied for third place, cycling {{convert|405|mi|km}}.{{cn|date=February 2018}} Around this time, he changed his first name to Ashrita ("protected by God" <ref name="most" /> in [[Sanskrit]]).<ref name="rt" /><ref name="WSJ" />
[[Image:GreatWallAshrita.jpeg|thumb|200px|right|Ashrita at the [[Great Wall of China]] in January 2005 breaking the Guinness record for the fastest mile on a [[kangaroo ball]].]]
===First record=== In 1979, Furman set his first official record by doing 27,000 [[jumping jack]]s.<ref name="GBR-2015" /> In 1986, Furman invented and set the record for underwater [[pogo stick]] jumping and introduced it on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' on [[April Fools' Day]].{{cn|date=February 2018}}
===Records around the world=== Furman has managed a [[health food store]] in [[Jamaica, Queens|Jamaica]], [[Queens]], [[New York City]],<ref name="health" /> [[New York (state)|New York]] since 1982. He is also a tour manager for his meditation group and is therefore able to travel extensively. As of 2014, Furman has set records in 40 countries. He completed his goal of breaking a record in all seven continents when he set the mile [[hula hoop]] record at [[Uluru]] (also known as Ayers Rock) in the Australian desert in 2003.<ref name = "theage" /> Furman has also set records at such famous landmarks as the [[Egyptian pyramids]] (distance [[pool cue]] balancing), [[Stonehenge]] (standing on a [[Swiss ball]]), the [[Eiffel Tower]] (most sit ups in an hour), the [[Great Wall of China]] (hopping on a [[kangaroo ball]]), [[Borobudur]] (Fastest time to run a mile while balancing a milk bottle on the head) and [[Angkor Wat]] ([[jumping rope]] on a pogo stick). While in [[China]], Furman broke the record for running 8 km (4.97 mi) on [[stilts]] in the fastest time (39 min. 56 sec.), a record which had stood since 1982.
[[Image:Stone henge.jpg|thumb|500px|left|Furman breaking the record for balancing on a [[Swiss ball]] (2 hours 16 mins 2 seconds) at [[Stonehenge]], July 22, 2003.]]
===Creating new records===
Furman has also been a pioneer in setting records in several new activities including landrowing. Using a converted [[indoor rower]] with wheels and brakes, Furman rowed {{convert|1500|mi|km}} in 16 days in [[Bali]] in 1991. Furman also developed the sport of gluggling, underwater juggling, which he did for 48 minutes at [[Kelly Tarlton's Sea Life Aquarium|Kelly Tarlton's Antarctic Encounter and Underwater World]] in [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]] in 2002 and distance sack racing, which Furman did for a mile while racing against a [[yak]] in [[Mongolia]] in 2007. On January 30, 2008, Furman unveiled his giant [[pencil]] – {{convert|76|ft|m}} long, 22,000 pounds (with 4,000 solid pounds of [[Pennsylvania]] [[graphite]]). The pencil was built in three weeks as a birthday gift for teacher [[Sri Chinmoy]] on 27 August 2007. Longer than the {{convert|65|ft|m|adj=on}} pencil outside the [[Malaysia]] HQ of stationers [[Faber-Castell]], it was transported from [[Queens, New York]], to the [[City Museum]] in [[St. Louis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=87830&in_page_id=34 |title=metro.co.uk, 'World's biggest pencil' draws in a crowd |publisher=[[Metro (British newspaper)]] |date=2008-01-29 |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref> In April 2009 Furman became the first person to hold 100 Guinness World Records at once.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Guinness World Records 2014|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-1-908843-15-9|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
[[Image:on-straight-with-sign.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Furman breaking the record for [[underwater cycling]] the longest distance (1.8 mi.) at [[Coimbra, Portugal]], September 2011.<ref name="uc" />]]
==See also== * [[Impossibility Challenger]]

revision.text:
'''Ask a Librarian''' is a live [[virtual reference]] service that offers online reference assistance to residents in the state of Florida. Ask a Librarian is an official service of the Florida Electronic Library and is administered by the [[Tampa Bay Library Consortium]] (TBLC).
Participating libraries provide users with virtual reference services via [[live chat]] software, text messaging, and e-mail forms which users can access through embedded links and widgets on their library’s official website. Live chat and text messaging are available from 10:00 a.m. to midnight EST from Sunday through Thursday, and from 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. EST on Friday and Saturday; the e-mail form is available to patrons 24 hours per day, seven days per week.<ref name="about">{{cite web|url=http://info.askalibrarian.org/about|title=AskALibrarian.org: About|work=Ask A Librarian News and Information|accessdate=2016-03-20}}</ref> As of March 2016, Ask a Librarian has 133 participating institutions including public libraries and library systems, K-12 libraries, and university and college libraries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://info.askalibrarian.org/participating-libraries/|title=Participating Libraries|website=Ask a Librarian News and Information|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref>
== History == Ask a Librarian began as a partnership between the [[College Center for Library Automation]] (CCLA) and TBLC in the interest of creating a statewide virtual reference service that would increase the presence of librarians on the internet.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Sachs|first=Diana|date=2005|title=Ask a Librarian: Florida’s Virtual Reference Service|url=|journal=Community & Junior College Libraries|volume=12|issue=4|pages=51–52|doi=10.1300/J107v12n04_06|pmid=}}<!--|access-date=2016-03-18--></ref> In 2002, the organizations successfully applied for a joint grant through the [[Library Services and Technology Act]] (LSTA) and were awarded $339,000 for the development and implementation of their pilot project as a service of the [[Florida Electronic Library]].<ref name=":0" />
The Ask a Librarian virtual reference service was officially activated on July 28, 2003.<ref name="about" /> [[Tampa Bay Area|Tampa Bay-area]] libraries were the first to participate, with [[Pasco County, Florida|Pasco County]] libraries joining shortly afterward.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:TTRB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0FCC97A666F1382A&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB5811D21E575|title=Librarians' Help Offered On Web|last=Richardson|first=Rachel|date=4 August 2003|newspaper=[[The Tampa Tribune]]|page=4|accessdate=2013-04-04}}</ref> Within the first year of operation, nearly 7,500 Floridians had used the service to get answers from a reference librarian.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:PBPB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=104BB78A4408DBED&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB5811D21E575|title=Library offering live, on-line help with research|last=Haase|first=Linda|date=25 August 2004|newspaper=[[The Palm Beach Post]]|page=1 (Neighborhood Post)|accessdate=2013-04-04}}</ref><ref name="Ward, J. 2010">Ward, J., & Barbier, P. (2010). Best Practices in Chat Reference Used by Florida's Ask a Librarian Virtual Reference Librarians. Reference Librarian, 51(1), 53-68. doi:10.1080/02763870903361854</ref> By August 19, 2007, Ask a Librarian had answered its 100,000th reference question.{{citation needed|date=March 2016|reason=I cannot find a reference for this statistic.}} As of February 2011, Ask a Librarian had logged over 274,000 live virtual reference sessions and e-mail questions.{{citation needed|date=March 2016|reason=The original reference no longer states this statistic. I have not yet found a replacement reference.}}
Ask a Librarian has made several efforts meet user reference needs on smartphones and other mobile devices. In October 2010, Ask a Librarian introduced a text messaging service to accompany their traditional chat service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://info.askalibrarian.org/2010/10/22/text-messaging-goes-live-on-monday-october-25th/|title=Text Messaging goes LIVE on Monday, October 25th|website=Ask a Librarian News and Information|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref> In 2012, the service introduced a mobile-friendly website interface for tablets and phones.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20120306/COLUMNISTS/203065001|title=Reference Questions Answered with Ask-A-Librarian|last=Nunez|first=Varrick|date=6 March 2012|newspaper=[[The Ledger]]|page=B9|accessdate=2013-04-04}}</ref><ref>Bishop, B., Sachs-Silveira, D., & Avet, T. (2011). Populating a Knowledge Base with Local Knowledge for Florida's Ask a Librarian Reference Consortium. Reference Librarian, 52(3), 197-207. doi:10.1080/02763877.2011.555289</ref> In April 2013, the service also launched the Ask A Librarian Mobile App, a mobile-friendly interface geared toward improving the user chat experience on smartphones and tablets.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://info.askalibrarian.org/2013/04/06/ask-a-librarian-mobile-app/|title=Ask a Librarian – Mobile App|website=Ask a Librarian News and Information|access-date=2016-03-20}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|1=http://www.askalibrarian.org/|mobile=http://www.askalibrarian.org/m}} * [http://info.askalibrarian.org/annual-reports/ Ask a Librarian Annual Reports ] * [http://info.askalibrarian.org/news/ Ask a Librarian News and Information]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ask A Librarian}} [[Category:Library resources]] [[Category:Libraries in Florida]] [[Category:Reference]]

page.title: Business Aviation Corporation v Rand Airport Holdings

revision.text:
'''''Business Aviation Corporation (Pty) Ltd and Another v Rand Airport Holdings (Pty) Ltd''''', an important case in the [[South African law of lease]], dealt with the lessee's entitlement in respect of improvement of lease property. The issue was whether Article 10 of the Rental Housing Act (RHA) applied: Specifically, did it apply in respect of urban and rural property?
The Supreme Court of Appeal held that the RHA applies only to rural tenements; therefore, it was a question of use.
== See also == * [[South African law of lease]]
== References == * ''Business Aviation Corporation (Pty) Ltd and Another v Rand Airport Holdings (Pty) Ltd'' 2006 (6) SA 605 (SCA).
[[Category:2006 in South African law]] [[Category:2006 in case law]] [[Category:Supreme Court of Appeal of South Africa cases]]
{{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Christian Joppke''' is a German political sociologist, Professor and chair in General Sociology at the [[University of Bern]], Switzerland.<ref>*{{cite web |url=http://www.soz.unibe.ch/content/ueber_uns/joppke/index_ger.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823200836/http://www.soz.unibe.ch/content/ueber_uns/joppke/index_ger.html |archivedate=2014-08-23 |df= }}</ref> He is the author of more than one hundred publications, monographs and manuscripts, and among the most widely cited authors in the field of [[immigration]]. Essentially a [[Criticism of multiculturalism|critic]] of [[multiculturalism]], Joppke is self-defined "a reactionary liberal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sociology.berkeley.edu/christian-joppke-1985 |title=Christian Joppke (1985) | UC Berkeley Sociology Department |publisher=Sociology.berkeley.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-23}}</ref>
== Biography ==
Joppke holds a PhD degree from the [[University of California at Berkeley]], United States. Previous appointments include the [[University of Southern California]], the [[European University Institute]], the [[University of British Columbia]], and [[International University Bremen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eudo-citizenship.eu/people/271-joppke-christian |title=Eudo Citizenship |publisher=Eudo-citizenship.eu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-23}}</ref>
== List of Books (Monographs) == * ''Is Multiculturalism Dead? Crisis and Persistence in the Constitutional State''. Cambridge: Polity, 2017. *''The Secular State Under Siege: Religion and Politics in Europe and America''. Cambridge: Polity, 2015. **Swedish translation published by Daidalos, Göteborg, 2015; Turkish and German translations in process. *''Legal Integration of Islam: A Transatlantic Comparison'' (with [[John Torpey]]). [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], Mass.: [[Harvard University Press]], 2013. *''Citizenship and Immigration.'' Cambridge: [[Polity]], 2010. **[[Japanese-Language Proficiency Test|Japanese]] translation published by [[Iwanami Shoten, Publishers|Iwanami Shoten]], [[Tokyo]], 2013. *''Veil: Mirror of Identity.'' Cambridge: Polity, 2009. **Japanese translation published by Hosei University Press, Tokyo, 2015. *''Selecting by Origin: Ethnic Migration in the Liberal State. ''Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press, 2005<ref>(included in a review of the “best” books on international migration published since 2000, by Roger Waldinger, ''Contemporary Sociology'' 42, May 2013, 349-363).</ref> *''Immigration and the Nation-State: The United States, Germany, and Great Britain.'' Oxford: [[Oxford University Press]], 1999. *''East German Dissidents and the Revolution of 1989: Social Movement in a Leninist Regime.'' London: Macmillan and New York: [[New York University Press]], 1995<ref>Named “Outstanding Academic Book for 1995” by [[Choice Magazine]]).</ref> *''Mobilizing Against Nuclear Energy: A Comparison of Germany and the United States.'' Berkeley and Los Angeles: [[University of California Press]], 1993.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soz.unibe.ch/content/ueber_uns/joppke/index_ger.html |title=Universität Bern - Institut für Soziologie - Prof. Dr. Christian Joppke |publisher=Soz.unibe.ch |date= |accessdate=2014-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823200836/http://www.soz.unibe.ch/content/ueber_uns/joppke/index_ger.html |archivedate=2014-08-23 |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
'''''Chroniques de France''''' or [[Chronicle]]s of [[France]] may refer to:
*''[[Grandes Chroniques de France]]'' - a vast compilation (13th-15th century) of material on the history of France. *''Chroniques des rois de France'' - a compilation (c.1220-1230) of material on the history of France by an anonymous author designated "Chantilly-Vatican".
{{disamb}}

revision.text:
This is a list of [[free and open-source software]] for [[geophysics|geophysical]] data processing and interpretation. The list is split into broad categories, depending on the intended use of the software and its scope of functions.
Notice that 'free and open-source' requires that the source code is available. Simple being 'free of charge' is not sufficient—see [[gratis versus libre]]. The reader interested in freeware (just free of charge) software is referred to the [[list of freeware geophysics software]].
==Reflection seismic processing packages== These are full-featured [[reflection seismology]] processing packages, with support for modeling, imaging, and inversion. They are relatively low-level and in some cases have their own data formats and involve learning an extensive syntax or meta-language.
<!-- In each table, for each term, link one instance only, usually the 1st, remove other WP:OVERLINK(s). --> {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%; table-layout: fixed; font-size: smaller; text-align: center;" |- style="background: #ececec" ! style="width:16em" | Name ! style="width:14em" | Description ! style="width:6em" | Originator ! style="width:4em" | License ! style="width:8em" | Platforms ! style="width:6em" | Language ! style="width:6em" | Notes |-
! IMAGE2SEGY<ref name="csic">{{cite web|url=http://www.icm.csic.es/geo/gma/graf2segy.html|title=IMAGE2SEGY|publisher=icm.csic.es|accessdate=2016-06-13}}</ref> | Image converter | Marcel.lí Farran, [http://www.icm.csic.es/ Institut de Ciències del Mar] | [[Creative Commons]] | Cross-platform | MATLAB | Needs MATLAB & SegyMAT |-

! fast<ref name="rice2">{{cite web|url=http://terra.rice.edu/department/faculty/zelt/fast.html|title=FAST|publisher=terra.rice.edu|accessdate=2016-06-13}}</ref> | 3D traveltime tomography | Colin Zelt, [[Rice University]] | Custom, non-commercial use only | Unix, Linux | Fortran 77, C | |-

! PyShottab<ref>http://seismic.ocean.dal.ca/utilities/pyShottab/index.html</ref> | Processing for ocean-bottom seismic | [[Dalhousie University]] | Unclear | Cross-platform | [[Python (programming language)|Python]] | [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] binary |-
! IGeoS (formerly SIA)<ref name="usask">{{cite web|url=http://seisweb.usask.ca/igeos|title=IGeoS (formerly SIA) geophysical and seismic processing and data analysis|publisher=seisweb.usask.ca|accessdate=2016-06-13}}</ref> | Geophysical processing and analysis | [[University of Saskatchewan]] | Custom, free for non-commercial use | Unix, Linux | C++ | Interfaces with [[Seismic Unix|SU]], GMT |-

Seizmo<ref name="wustl">{{cite web|url=http://epsc.wustl.edu/~ggeuler/codes/m/seizmo/|title=Project SEIZMO - A Matlab & Octave Toolbox for Earthquake Seismology|publisher=epsc.wustl.edu|accessdate=2016-06-13}}</ref> | Global seismic analysis | Garrett Euler, [[Washington University in St. Louis]] | Unclear | Cross-platform | MATLAB | Octave-compatible |-

WheelerLab <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amosu|first=Adewale|last2=Sun|first2=Yuefeng|date=2017|title=WheelerLab: An interactive program for sequence stratigraphic analysis of seismic sections, outcrops and well sections and the generation of chronostratigraphic sections and dynamic chronostratigraphic sections|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352711016300401|journal=SoftwareX|volume=6|pages=19–24|doi=10.1016/j.softx.2016.12.003|bibcode=2017SoftX...6...19A}}</ref> | Sequence Stratigraphic Analysis and Chronostratigraphic Analysis (Wheeler Diagrams) | Adewale Amosu & Yuefeng Sun, Texas A&M University | Modified BSD | Cross-Platform | MATLAB | Needs Matlab and SegyMAT |}

revision.text:
{{Infobox dot-com company | name = DealNews Inc. | logo = File:Dealnews_logo.png | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{url|http://dealnews.com/}} | company_type = | foundation = 1997 | location = [[Huntsville, Alabama|Huntsville]], [[Alabama]], [[U.S]] | industry = [[Comparison shopping website]] | founder = Daniel de Grandpre and D. Richard Moss<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of dealnews.com, Inc.|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=7728317|publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek|accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref> | products = | website_type = | language = English | advertising = | registration = | current_status = Active }} '''DealNews''' is a [[comparison shopping website]] for [[consumer electronics]], [[apparel]], and other products. Founded in 1997 by Daniel de Grandpre, the website was included in [[PCWorld (magazine)|PCWorld's]] “100 Best Products of 2006 List".<ref>{{cite web|title=The 100 Best Products of 2006|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/125706/article.html|publisher=PC World|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> According to [[Alexa Internet|Alexa Internet, Inc.]], DealNews.com is a top 1,000 website in the USA.<ref>{{cite web|title=DealNews Data|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/dealnews.com|publisher=Alexa.Com|accessdate=25 January 2014}}</ref> During the [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] season, the site publishes data driven shopping reports, including deal predictions and price benchmarks for various categories. The DealNews app is available for both [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android smartphones]]. The company is headquartered in [[Huntsville, Alabama|Huntsville]], [[Alabama|AL]].
==History== The website was launched in 1997 by Daniel de Grandpre and Richard Moss as deal-mac.<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of dealnews.com, Inc.|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=7728317|publisher=BloomBerg Business Week|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Site Is Mac Daddy of Apple Deals|url=https://www.wired.com/gadgets/mac/news/2004/08/64661|publisher=Wired.com|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> Initially, the website posted online prices for [[Apple Macintosh]] products. Later, in 1999, the business was renamed as DealNews.com to include [[PC hardware]], [[software]], [[DVD|DVD movies]], [[TV]] and [[apparel]] deals as well. DealNews.com also operates the DealCoupon.com domain.<ref>{{cite web|title=A look back ... 10 years of our Macworld Expo coverage|url=http://dealmac.com/features/A-look-back-...-10-years-of-our-Macworld-Expo-coverage/208018.html|publisher=DealMac.com|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== DealNews.com was declared No 1 on the "Top 10 Black Friday Sites List" by [[PC Mag]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 10 Black Friday Site List|url=https://www.pcmag.com/slideshow_viewer/0,3253,l=234260&a=234260&po=1,00.asp|publisher=PC Mag|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> and was listed as one of the "Best Retail Deals Coupon Sites" by [[Yahoo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=15 Sites to Help You Find Amazing Holiday Deals ... - Yahoo Shopping|url=http://shine.yahoo.com/work-money/best-coupon-sites-113300697.html|publisher=Yahoo.com|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> DealNews was listed at #24 on [[PC World|PC World's]] "100 Best Products of 2006 List". The site was also included on the 2011 "Gold and Excellence Awards" list from [[Top Ten Reviews]]<ref>{{cite web|title=dealnews|url=http://hot-deals-review.toptenreviews.com/dealnews.com-review.html|publisher=Top Ten Reviews|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> and was declared an “Editor's Favorite” by the ''[[Washington Post]]'';<ref>{{cite web|title=Avoid the Crowds and Save Money Online|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/11/27/AR2009112704011.html|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> Stephanie Rosenbloom in a 2011 ''[[New York Times]]'' article included the website in a list of recommended sites, describing it as “credible and well researched".<ref>{{cite news|last=STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM|title=Holiday Shopping at the Last Minute? No Worries Online|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/15/fashion/shopping-at-the-last-minute-no-worries-online.html?_r=0|publisher=NY Times|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>” The website has been named as "Official Honoree" in the 11th and 12th [[Webby Awards|Annual Webby Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Winners Webby Awards - 2007|url=http://winners.webbyawards.com/2007/web/general-website/services/honorees|publisher=Webby Awards|accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Winners 200 - Webby Awards|url=http://winners.webbyawards.com/2008/web/general-website/services/honorees|publisher=Webby Awards|accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref>
==Black Friday predictions== DealNews.com publishes a Black Friday predictions report annually; the report provides practical shopping advice and price benchmarks. Its sixth annual report was released on 1 October 2013. In the 2012 predictions report, 73% of DealNews’ forecasts were found to be accurate, either predicting the correct price or finding a price that was even lower.<ref>{{cite web|title=DealNews Releases it's 2013 Black Friday Predictions|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/01/al-dealnews-idUSnBw016775a+100+BSW20131001|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
==Mobile applications== The DealNews app is available for [[iOS]] and Android smartphones.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://applenapps.com/app-pick/the-best-black-friday-apps-to-score-every-bargain.html |title=The Best Black Friday Apps To Score Every Bargain |publisher=Applenapps.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> As of February 2014, the Android app has been downloaded between 100,000 - 500,000 times.<ref>{{cite web|title=Black Friday App|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.semaphoremobile.blackfriday.android&feature=more_from_developer#?t=W251bGwsMSwxLDEwMiwiY29tLnNlbWFwaG9yZW1vYmlsZS5ibGFja2ZyaWRheS5hbmRyb2lkIl0|publisher=Google Play|accessdate=8 March 2014}}</ref> DealNews has also introduced a Black Friday app for iOS and Android.<ref>{{cite web|title=YOUR MONEY-Smartphone apps for last minute pre-shopping|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/27/blackfriday-apps-factbox-idUSL2N0J71OP20131127|work=Mitch Lipka|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Top 5 Black Friday Gotchas|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/11/26/urnidgns852573c40069388000257679006ee02a-idUS124616275820091126|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> In 2012, DealNews RSS was selected for the Best Mobile App Award.<ref>{{cite web|title=DealNews RSS|url=http://www.bestmobileappawards.com/app-submission/dealnews-rss|publisher=Best Mobile App Awards LLC|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== After the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|2004 Indonesian Tsunami]], DealNews and its readers raised over $10,000. In the aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]] in 2005, both parties collectively raised $107,392 for the Red Cross relief efforts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dealnews.com/deals/dealnews-Hurricane-Relief-fundraiser-totals-107-392/95132.html |title=dealnews Hurricane Relief fundraiser totals $107,392 |publisher=Dealnews.com |date=2005-09-08 |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> The company also raised $100,000 in response to the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]].<ref>{{cite web|title=DealNews Will Match Up to $50,000 in donations for Haiti Relief|url=http://dealnews.com/features/dealnews-Will-Match-Up-to-50-000-in-donations-for-Haiti-Relief/343351.html|publisher=DealNews.com|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=DealNews matches Haiti donations 100%|url=http://bargainbabe.com/dealnews-matches-haiti-donations-100/|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
[[Category:Comparison shopping websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1997]]

revision.comment: /* See also */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[open source]] → [[open-source software|open-source]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = Delicious Library | logo = deliciouslibrary3logo.png | screenshot = Deliciouslibrary3screenshot.jpg | caption = Screenshot of Delicious Library 3 | developer = [[Delicious Monster]] | released = November 2004 | latest release version = 3.7.1 | operating system = [[Mac OS X Mountain Lion]] and later | platform = Apple Macintosh | genre = [[Digital asset management]] | license = [[Shareware]] | website = {{URL|delicious-monster.com}} }} '''Delicious Library''' is a [[digital asset management]] app for [[Mac OS X]], developed by [[Delicious Monster]] to allow the user to keep track and manage their physical collections of [[books]], [[movies]], [[Compact Disc|CDs]], and [[video games]].
The software was initially released in November 2004, with $250,000 in sales in its first month.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/gadgets/mac/news/2005/01/66276 |title=Monster Fueled by Caffeine |accessdate=2008-05-03 |last=Kahney |first=Leander |date=2005-01-14 |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130429014759/http://www.wired.com/gadgets/mac/news/2005/01/66276 |archivedate=2013-04-29 |df= }}</ref> Delicious Library 2 was released officially on May 27, 2008, although the final version was available from March 25. Delicious Library 3 is available from the Mac App Store and the developers website for Macintosh systems running OS 10.8 or higher.<ref>http://www.delicious-monster.com</ref>
==Features== * Enter media items in the following ways: ** Manually ** Inputting the [[ISBN]] or [[Universal Product Code|UPC]] ** Importing the library from another application (like [[Bookpedia]]) ** Drag-and-dropping an [[Amazon.com]] [[URL]] ** Scanning barcodes using a [[Bluetooth]] scanner, an [[iSight]] camera, or a USB-keyboard-type [[barcode]] scanner (such as a modified [[CueCat]]) * Integration with [[Mac OS X]]'s [[Address Book (application)|Address Book]] application to allow "lending management" * Voice Search * [[iPod]] syncing * [[Spotlight (software)|Spotlight]] compatibility * Mini Bookshelf [[Dashboard widget]] * Printouts of specific shelves or entire libraries * Custom Collections allow the user to create their own "shelves" to organize their [[wikt:media|media]].
==Easter eggs== *When a ''[[Star Wars]]'' item is added, Delicious Library says, "I am your father", in the whisper voice *When a ''[[Harry Potter]]'' item is added, Delicious Library says "[[Lord Voldemort|Voldemort]]", in the whisper voice *When ''[[A Brief History of Time]]'' is added, the library talks about science concepts in a mock-synthesized voice *When ''[[Rock Band (video game)|Rock Band]]'' is added, Delicious Library sings a portion of "[[Run to the Hills]]" by [[Iron Maiden]] in the whisper voice
==Mobile apps== The only Delicious Library app was withdrawn from the iOS App Store in July 2009. Amazon had asked for the app to be removed due to violation of the Amazon API terms and conditions section 4e "(e) You will not, without our express prior written approval requested via this link, use any Product Advertising Content on or in connection with any site or application designed or intended for use with a mobile phone or other handheld device."<ref>http://reviews.cnet.com/8301-19512_7-10281670-233.html</ref> NB: The terms and conditions have since been updated.<ref>https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/gp/advertising/api/detail/agreement.html</ref>
===Awards=== *[[Apple Design Award]] Best Mac OS X Leopard Application 2007 Winner *[[Apple Design Award]] Best Mac OS X user experience 2005 winner *[[Apple Design Award]] Best product new to Mac OS X 2005 runner-up *[[Macworld Conference & Expo|Macworld]] SF 2005 showtime award winner *[[Macworld Conference & Expo|Macworld]] 2005 Eddy winner *[[O'Reilly Innovators Award]] 2004 (First place winner)
==See also== *[[MediaMan]], a similar application for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] *[[GCstar]], an [[open-source software|open-source]] [[cross-platform]] similar application available for Windows, [[Linux]], and Mac OS X.
==References== <references/>
== External links == * {{official website|http://www.delicious-monster.com/}} * [https://getsatisfaction.com/deliciousmonster Official forums] * [https://arstechnica.com/reviews/apps/delicious-library.ars Review of Delicious Library]
[[Category:MacOS-only software]] [[Category:Personal information managers]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox comic book title |title=Diceman |image= Diceman5.jpg |imagesize= 240 |caption=Cover of ''Diceman'' no. 5 (painted by [[Hunt Emerson]]) |alt=The cover is titled "2000 AD's Diceman." In the corner a caption reads "You are Ronald Reagan" and at the bottom a caption reads "Can you stop the BIG BANG?" In the foreground is a caricature of President [[Ronald Reagan]], carrying a large gun shaped like a tank, and wearing shoulder-pads with the stars and stripes on. Beside him a monkey sits on a globe which has a red button on the North Pole; the monkey is pressing the button. In the background a nuclear explosion destroys a city. The picture is signed by Hunt Emerson. The issue is priced at £1.45. |schedule=Every 2 months |format=[[Comics anthology]] |publisher=[[Fleetway]] |date=Feb. 1986 – Oct. 1986 |issues=5 |main_char_team= |writers= |artists= |pencillers= |inkers= |letterers= |colorists= |editors=Simon Geller |creative_team_month= |creative_team_year= |creators= |subcat=Fleetway and IPC Comics |sort=Dice Man (comics) |nonUS=y }} '''''Diceman''''' was a short-lived British comic which ran for five issues in 1986. It was a spin-off from ''[[2000 AD (comic)|2000 AD]]'' and was devised by [[Pat Mills]], who also wrote almost all of the stories. It was edited by [[Simon Geller (comics)|Simon Geller]], but purported to be edited by a monster called Mervyn. The stories were designed to be played like [[gamebook]]s. Each issue contained two or three such stories and was published every two months. ==Stories== The comic mostly contained stories based on characters who already appeared regularly in ''2000 AD''. Its [[eponymous]] character Diceman, also known as Rick Fortune, was created specially for the comic (by Pat Mills and [[Graham Manley]]), but did not appear until the second issue. Fortune was a "psychic investigator", a 1930s American private detective with [[psionics|psionic powers]]. He also had a pair of stone dice, recovered from the ruins of [[Atlantis]], which he could use to summon various powers including a three-headed lizard demon called Astragal to assist him. The ''Diceman'' strip was different from the others in that the reader not only had to avoid being killed, he also ran the risk of being driven insane (if his "sanity score" dropped to zero). The only other story in the comic which was not derived from ''2000 AD'' was "You are [[Ronald Reagan]] in: ''Twilight's Last Gleaming''", a satirical spoof in which the reader, playing the part of the American president, must prevent nuclear war breaking out. In contrast to the strip Diceman, this strip also had a sanity score, but if it got too ''high'', then the Secret Service assume that the president must have been replaced with an imposter (a comment on Reagan's perceived intellectual limitations). This game was exceptionally difficult compared with the others in the comic, as the player must make irrational decisions to avoid arrest and execution, while trying to make the right decisions to prevent a nuclear launch by either side. In fact the player transpires to have very little control over the outcome, and almost every option inevitably results in [[World War III]], suggesting that nuclear diplomacy is very difficult to control once [[Cold War]] tensions have begun. The other strips which appeared in ''Dice Man'' were ''[[Judge Dredd]], [[Nemesis the Warlock]], [[Sláine (comics)|Sláine]], [[Rogue Trooper]]'', ''[[Torquemada (comics)|Torquemada]]'' and ''[[ABC Warriors]]''. ==Creators== ===Writers=== * [[Pat Mills]]: ''Diceman, Nemesis, Sláine, Rogue Trooper, ABC Warriors, Judge Dredd ''(with John Wagner)'', You Are Ronald Reagan!'' * Simon Gellar: ''Rogue Trooper'' * [[John Wagner]]: ''Judge Dredd'' (with Pat Mills) ===Artists=== * [[Steve Dillon]]: ''Diceman, ABC Warriors, Rogue Trooper'' * [[Bryan Talbot]]: ''Judge Dredd, Nemesis'' * [[Kevin O'Neill (comics)|Kevin O'Neill]]: ''Nemesis'' * [[David Lloyd (comics)|David Lloyd]]: ''Sláine'' * Nik Williams: ''Sláine'' * [[Mark Farmer]]: ''Sláine'' * [[Graham Manley]]: ''Diceman'' * [[John Ridgway (comic artist)|John Ridgway]]: ''Diceman'' * [[Mike Collins (comics)|Mike Collins]]: ''Rogue Trooper'' * [[Hunt Emerson]]: ''You Are Ronald Reagan!'' ==List of stories== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-1-of-2}} '''Judge Dredd'''

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = DreamsTime.com | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Stock photography]], [[stock footage]], [[Production music|stock music]] | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = {{Start date and age|2004}} | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Brentwood, Tennessee]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people =Serban Enache ([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]]) | products =Stock Photos by DreamsTime, DreamsTime Companion | services = Licensing of stock media | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees =51-100 | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = {{URL|www.DreamsTime.com}} }}
'''DreamsTime.com''' is an online [[royalty-free]] [[microstock]] provider based in [[Brentwood, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/dreamstime|title=Dreamstime {{!}} crunchbase|website=www.crunchbase.com|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.digitalmedialicensing.org/?p=3842|title=Dreamtime New Artificial Intelligence System {{!}} DMLA|website=blog.digitalmedialicensing.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/photography/dreamstime-ai-photo-editor/|title=Hey photographers, AI is helping editors determine which photos make the cut|date=2017-03-17|work=Digital Trends|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/dreamstime-designers-also-selected-these-stock-photos/|title=Dreamstime Incorporates Shared Images on Facebook Into New Personalization Feature|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/dreamstime-launches-wordpress-plugin/|title=Dreamstime Launches Wordpress Plugin for Stock Photos|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wordpress.org/plugins/dreamstime-stock-photos/|title=Dreamstime Stock Photos|website=WordPress.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>
==History== The company started in the year 2000 as a website selling [[royalty-free]] images and was redesigned as a “community enabled” microstock provider in 2004, entering the market after its rivals [[iStock]] and [[Shutterstock]].<ref name="diaries">{{cite web|last1=Torrens|first1=Lee|title=Dreamstime|url=http://www.microstockdiaries.com/dreamstime.html|website=Microstock Diaries|accessdate=6 August 2017|date=10 June 2007}}</ref> According to [[Nashville Business Journal]], the company had sales approaching $10 million on the year 2007 with revenue growing expected to grow to $15 million in 2008.<ref name="bizjournals1">{{cite news|last1=Bryant|first1=Linda|title=Dreamstime has $100M dreams|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/stories/2007/12/24/smallb1.html|accessdate=6 August 2017|publisher=Nashville Business Journal|date=23 December 2007}}</ref> Their image database consisted of 25 million files from 170.000 different contributors<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.digitalmedialicensing.org/?p=2207|title=Dreamstime Surpasses 25 Million Images {{!}} DMLA|website=blog.digitalmedialicensing.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref> from all around the world in the year 2014 and of 49 million files in November 2016.<ref name="bizjournals2">{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Harrison|title=Why a Brentwood CFO and single mom doesn't stress out over work-life balance|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/blog/2014/04/brentwood-cfo-and-singlemom-says-work-life-balance.html|accessdate=6 August 2017|publisher=Nashville Business Journal|date=3 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="insider">{{cite web|last1=Gibson|first1=Steve|title=Dreamstime|url=http://microstockinsider.com/site_reviews/dreamstime|website=Microstock Insider|accessdate=6 August 2017|date=3 November 2016}}</ref>
==Facilities and staff== Dreamstime is headquartered in Brentwood, Tennessee, USA. Serban Enache is the CEO, Owner & Co-Founder of Dreamstime, a platform with 64 million stock images, and is currently the world’s largest stock community with 18 million users.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hdfmagazine.com/ep-101-serban-enache-co-founder-dreamstime/|title=Ep. 101 – Serban Enache – Co-Founder of Dreamstime - Hustle & Deal Flow|date=2017-04-18|work=Hustle & Deal Flow|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://petapixel.com/2012/06/02/stock-photography-for-your-facebook-timeline/|title=Stock Photography for Your Facebook Timeline|date=2012-06-02|work=PetaPixel|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cepic.org/news/dreamstime-introduces-unlimited-extended-licenses|title=NEWS {{!}} CEPIC|website=cepic.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>
==Business model== As a founding member of the European Tech Alliance] (EUTA),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://eutechalliance.eu/?portfolio=dreamstime|title=DreamsTime - Eutech Alliance|work=Eutech Alliance|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref> DreamsTime entered the market to compete with traditional [[stock photography]] providers, differentiating themselves with their business model where their license prices and operational costs are kept low and their efficiency is kept high with "optimized workflows and monitoring systems".<ref name="bizjournals1" /> Their stock photographs are licensed around the world through the website with the individual contributors curating their own image portfolios and providing their own image info and search keywords with the company handling image hosting and providing the search tools to find the images.<ref name="bizjournals1" /><ref name="business20">{{cite news|last1=Levine|first1=Robert|title=Photo wars: A $2 billion business gets rough|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/business2/business2_archive/2007/04/01/8403372/index.htm|accessdate=6 August 2017|publisher=Business 2.0|date=4 April 2007}}</ref> Like most other [[microstock]] companies, DreamsTime accepts anyone as contributor and relies on them to grow their file database.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite news|last1=Taub|first1=Eric A|title=When Are Photos Like Penny Stocks? When They Sell|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/05/technology/circuits/05syndicate.html|accessdate=6 August 2017|publisher=NY Times|date=5 June 2007}}</ref> The images are licensed as [[royalty free]], meaning one license has unlimited uses. Prices of the licenses images vary from $0.20 to thousands of dollars, of which the contributor receives a percentage.<ref name="bizjournals2" /> Besides [[stock photography]] and [[illustrations]] the company also allows curation of [[stock footage]].<ref name="bizjournals2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/creativity/2015/05/05/dreamstime-launches-on-the-go-stock-photo-search-for-ios-and-android|title=Dreamstime Launches On-the-Go Stock Photo Search|last=Dove|first=Jackie|date=2015-05-05|work=The Next Web|access-date=2017-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2004, still an era without Facebook and certainly no big data AIs would tell, for example, what color code the app should use. In 2011, DreamsTime reports record year with more than 4.2 million customers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stockphototalk.com/the_stock_photo_industry_/2011/12/dreamstime-reports-record-year-with-more-than-42-million-customers.html|title=DreamsTime Reports Record Year With More Than 4.2 Million Customers|website=Recent Stock Photo Industry Press Releases|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>
As of September 2017, DreamsTime numbers 18,000,000 registered members, more than 300,000 contributing photographers and over 64,000,000 photos, illustrations, cliparts and vectors. With unique visitors exceeding 11,000,000 monthly, the agency occupies the 2nd place in stock photography audience and image licensing worldwide. (December 2007 historical data: 500,000 registered members, 26,000 contributors, 2,000,000 images online and 4,000,000 unique views).
DreamsTimes' imagery is targeted for individuals, private sector and [[Fortune 500]] companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2017: Who Made the List|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-04}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Photography}} *[[Stock photography]] / [[microstock photography]] *[[Royalty free]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Stock photographies}} * [http://www.DreamsTime.com DreamsTime.com] * [https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User-Generated_Content_in_Education/Image_Content Wikibooks:User-Generated Content in Education]
[[Category:Stock photography]]

{{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = Ethel Tobach | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1921|11|07}} | birth_place = Miaskovka, [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = {{death date and age |2015|08|14|1921|11|07}} | death_place = [[Wayland, Massachusetts|Wayland]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = | pronounce = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = Soviet | fields = [[Psychology]] | workplaces = [[NYU Medical Center]]
[[Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic]]
[[American Museum of Natural History]]
[[New York University]]
[[Yeshiva University]]
[[City University of New York]] | patrons = | education = [[Hunter College]] (B.A., 1949)
[[New York University]] (M.A., 1952; Ph.D, 1957) | alma_mater = | thesis_title = A study of 'autonomic reactivity' in mice as related to developmental environment, approach response impedance, avoidance conditioning rate and difficult discrimination training | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1957 | doctoral_advisor = [[T. C. Schneirla]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Comparative psychology]]
[[Peace psychology]] | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Kurt Lewin]] Award from the [[Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues]] (1993) | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = {{marriage|Charles Tobach|1947|2015}} | partner = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Ethel Tobach''' (November 7, 1921 – August 14, 2015) was a Soviet [[psychologist]] known for her work in [[comparative psychology|comparative]] and [[peace psychology]].{{Cite journal |last=Greenberg |first=Gary |date=2015-01-01 |title=Ethel Tobach, November 7, 1921 – August 15, 2015 |url=https://escholarship.org/uc/item/86j6n2w8 |journal=International Journal of Comparative Psychology |language=en |volume=28 |issue=1 |issn=0889-3667}}{{Cite journal |last=McKay |first=Susan A. |last2=Roe |first2=Mícheál D. |last3=Wessells |first3=Michael G. |date=2008 |title=Pioneers in U.S. Peace psychology: Ethel Tobach. |url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1080/10781910701839643 |journal=Peace and Conflict: Journal of Peace Psychology |language=en |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=1–14 |doi=10.1080/10781910701839643 |issn=1532-7949}} ==Early life and education== Tobach was born on November 7, 1921 in Miaskovka, [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]], which was then part of the [[Soviet Union]]. Both of Tobach's parents were [[Jew]]ish, which led to them and their daughter having to flee the country to avoid [[pogrom]]s soon after Tobach was born. They initially fled to [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]], but after Tobach's father died when she was nine months old, she and her mother moved to [[Philadelphia]] in the [[United States]]. Tobach and her mother lived in Philadelphia until they moved to [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] when Tobach was ten years old. She became interested in psychology after enrolling at [[Hunter College]] in 1937. She received her B.A. from Hunter College in 1949, graduating [[Phi Beta Kappa]]. She then enrolled at [[New York University]] (NYU), where she received her M.A. in 1952 and her Ph.D. in 1957 under the supervision of [[T. C. Schneirla]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.feministvoices.com/ethel-tobach/ |title=Ethel Tobach |last=Lewis |first=Rokisha |website=Psychology's Feminist Voices |language=en |access-date=2018-07-06}} ==Career== After taking one of Schneirla's comparative psychology class at NYU, in which she got an A, Tobach persuaded Schneirla to give her a job at the [[American Museum of Natural History]]. She would continue to work at the American Museum of Natural History for the rest of her career. During her career, she also served on the faculty of NYU, Hunter College, the [[CUNY]] [[Graduate Center, CUNY|Graduate Center]], and [[Yeshiva University]].{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qGAeCwAAQBAJ |title=Comparative Psychology: A Handbook |last=Greenberg |first=Gary |last2=Haraway |first2=Maury M. |date=September 1998 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781136794513 |pages=18 |language=en}} ===Positions in learned societies=== In 1964, she was a co-founder of the [[Animal Behavior Society]]. In 1972, she became vice president of the [[New York Academy of Sciences]]. In 1983, she and Gary Greenberg founded the [[International Society for Comparative Psychology]]. She subsequently served as the Society's first president. In 1984, she was named president of the [[American Psychological Association]] (APA)'s Division of Comparative and Physiological Psychology, holding this position until 1985. She was the president of the [[Eastern Psychological Association]] from 1987 to 1988.{{Cite web |url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/Tobach-Ethel |title=Ethel Tobach |website=Jewish Women's Archive |language=en |access-date=2018-07-06}} In 2004, she served as president of the APA's Division of Peace Psychology. ==Honors and awards== Tobach received the [[Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues]]' Kurt Lewin Award, the society's most prestigious award, in 1993. In 2003, she received the APA's Gold Medal Award for Life Achievement in Psychology in the Public Interest. ==Personal life and death== Tobach married Charles Tobach, a photojournalist, in 1947; he subsequently persuaded her to apply to the Ph.D. program in psychology at NYU.{{Cite journal |last=Greenberg |first=Gary |date=January 2016 |title=Ethel Tobach (1921–2015) |url=http://psycnet.apa.org/buy/2016-00913-008 |journal=American Psychologist |volume=71 |issue=1 |pages=75}} She died in her sleep on August 14, 2015 in [[Wayland, MA|Wayland]], [[Massachusetts]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.animalbehaviorsociety.org/NEWSLETTERS/60-4/memorial.php |title=Memorials |date=November 2015 |website=Newsletter of the Animal Behavior Society |access-date=2018-07-06}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/Tobach-Ethel Ethel Tobach] at [[Jewish Women's Archive]] *[https://www.feministvoices.com/ethel-tobach/ Ethel Tobach] at [[Psychology's Feminist Voices]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tobach, Ethel}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Russian women academics]] [[Category:Russian psychologists]] [[Category:Women psychologists]] [[Category:Russian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Ukrainian psychologists]] [[Category:Comparative psychologists]] [[Category:Hunter College alumni]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:American Museum of Natural History]] [[Category:New York University faculty]] [[Category:Yeshiva University faculty]] [[Category:Russian Jews]] [[Category:Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic people]]

revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=March 2017}} The '''''Gallia Christiana''''', a type of work of which there have been several editions, is a documentary catalogue or list, with brief historical notices, of all the Catholic dioceses and abbeys of France from the earliest times, also of their occupants.
== First efforts ==
In 1621 [[Jean Chenu]], an ''[[avocat]]'' at the [[Parlement of Paris]], published ''Archiepiscoporum et episcoporum Galliæ chronologica historia''. Nearly a third of the bishops are missing, and the episcopal succession as given by Chenu was very incomplete. In 1626, Claude Robert, a priest of [[Langres]], published with the approbation of [[André Fremiot]], Archbishop of Bourges, a ''Gallia Christiana''.<ref>''Gallia christiana, in qua regni Franciae ditionumque vicinarum dioeceses et in iis praesules describuntur''; cura et labore Claudii Roberti,.... Felicibus auspiciis illustrissimi et reverendissimi D. Andreae Fremyot, archiepiscopi, patriarchae bituricensis, Aquitanarium primatis. Lutetiae, 1626 (BnF catalogue general)</ref> He entered a large number of churches outside of [[Gaul]], and gave a short history of the [[metropolitan see]]s, cathedrals, and abbeys.
== The Samarthani ==
Two brothers de Sainte-Marthe, Scévole (1571–1650) and Louis (1571–1656), appointed [[historiographer royal|royal historiographers]] of France in 1620, had assisted Chenu and Robert. At the [[assembly of the French Clergy]] in 1626, a number of prelates commissioned these brothers to compile a more definitive work. They died before the completion of their work, and it was issued in 1656 by the sons of [[Scévole de Sainte-Marthe (1571–1650)|Scévole de Sainte-Marthe]], [[Pierre de Sainte-Marthe]] (1618–90), himself historiographer of France, [[Abel de Sainte-Marthe]] (1620–71), theologian, and later general of the [[Oratory (worship)|Oratory]], and [[Nicolas-Charles de Sainte-Marthe]] (1623–62), prior of [[Claunay]]. On 13 September 1656, the Sainte-Marthe brothers were presented to the assembly of the French Clergy, who accepted the dedication of the work on condition that a passage suspected of [[Jansenism]] be suppressed. The work formed four volumes [[in folio]], the first for the [[archdiocese]]s, the second and third for the dioceses, and the fourth for the abbeys, all in alphabetical order.<ref>The title was ''Gallia Christiana, qua series omnia archiepiscoporum, episcoporum et abbatum Franciæ vicinarumque ditionum ab origine ecclesiarum ad nostra tempora per quattor tomos deducitur, et probator ex antiquæ fidei manuscriptis Vaticani, regnum, principum tabulariis omnium Galliæ cathedralium et abbatarium''.</ref> It reproduced a large number of manuscripts. Defects and omissions, however, were obvious. The Sainte-Marthe brothers themselves announced in their preface the early appearance of a second edition corrected and enlarged.
As early as 1660 the Jesuit [[Jean Colomb]] published at Lyons the ''Noctes Blancalandanæ'', which contains certain additions to the work of the Samarthani, as the brothers and their successors are often called. "The name of Sainte-Marthe", wrote Voltaire, "is one of those of which the country has most reason to be proud." The edition promised by the Sainte-Marthe brothers did not appear.
== Revision by the Maurists ==
In 1710 the Assembly of the French Clergy offered four thousand livres to [[Denys de Sainte-Marthe]] (1650–1725), a Benedictine monk of the [[Congregation of Saint-Maur]], renowned for his polemics against the Trappist [[Abbé de Rancé]] on the subject of monastic studies, on condition that he should bring the revision of the ''Gallia Christiana'' to a successful conclusion, that the first volume should appear at the end of four years, and that his Congregation should continue the undertaking after his death. Through his efforts the first volume appeared in 1715, devoted to the ecclesiastical provinces of Albi, Aix, Arles, Avignon, and Auch. In 1720 he produced the second volume dealing with the provinces of Bourges and Bordeaux; and in 1725 the third, which treated Cambrai, Cologne, and Embrun.
After his death the Benedictines issued the fourth volume (1728) on Lyons, and the fifth volume (1731) on Mechelen and Mainz. Between 1731 and 1740, on account of the controversies over the Bull ''[[Unigenitus]]'', Dom [[Félix Hodin]] and Dom [[Etienne Brice]], who were preparing the latter volumes of the ''Gallia Christiana'', were expelled from [[Saint-Germain-des-Prés]]. They returned to Paris in 1739 and issued the sixth volume, dealing with Narbonne, also (1744) the seventh and eighth volumes on Paris and its [[suffragan see]]s. [[Père Duplessis]] united his efforts with theirs, and the ninth and tenth volumes, both on the [[province of Reims]], appeared in 1751. The eleventh volume (1759) dealing with the [[province of Rouen]] was issued by Père [[Pierre Henri]] and Dom [[Jacques Taschereau]]. In 1770 the twelfth volume on the [[province of Sens]] and [[province of Tarentaise]] appeared, and in 1785 the thirteenth, on the provinces of Toulouse and Trier.
At the outbreak of the revolution, four volumes were lacking: Tours, Besançon, Utrecht, and Vienne. Barthélemy Hauréau published (in 1856, 1860 and 1865), for the provinces of Tours, Besançon and Vienne, respectively, and according to the Benedictine method, the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth volumes of the ''Gallia Christiana''.
The province of Utrecht alone has no place in this great collection, but this defect has been remedied in part by the ''Bullarium Trajectense'', edited by [[Gisbert Brom]], and extending from the earliest times to 1378 (The Hague, 1891–96).
The new ''Gallia Christiana'', of which volumes I to V and XI to XIII were reprinted by Dom [[Paul Piolin]] between 1870 and 1877, and volumes VI to IX and XII by the publisher H. Welter, places after each metropolitan see its suffragan sees, and after each see the abbeys belonging to it. The original documents, instead of encumbering the body of the articles, are inserted at the end of each diocese under in a section titled ''Instrumenta''. This colossal work does great honour to the Benedictines and to the Sainte-Marthe family. "The name of Sainte-Marthe", wrote Voltaire, "is one of those of which the country has most reason to be proud."
== Later works ==
In 1774 the Abbé [[Hugues du Temps]], vicar-general of Bordeaux, undertook in seven volumes an abridgement of the ''Gallia'' under the title "Le clergé de France" of which only four volumes appeared. About 1867 [[Honoré Fisquet]] undertook the publication of an episcopal history of France ([http://gallica.bnf.fr/Catalogue/noticesInd/FRBNF34044240.htm]''La France Pontificale''), in which, for the early period, he utilized the ''Gallia'', at the same time bringing the history of each diocese down to modern times. Twenty-two volumes appeared.
[[Canon Albanès]] projected a complete revision of the ''Gallia Christiana'', each ecclesiastical province to form a volume. Albanès, who was one of the first scholars to search the Lateran and Vatican libraries, in his efforts to determine the initial years of some episcopal reigns, found occasionally either the acts of election or the Bulls of provision. He hoped in this way to remove certain suppositious bishops who had been introduced to fill gaps in the catalogues, but died in 1897 before the first volume appeared. Through the use of his notes and the efforts of Canon [[Ulysse Chevalier]] three addition volumes of this "Gallia Christiana (novissima)", treating Arles, Aix, and Marseilles, appeared at Montbéliard.
== See also == * [[Catholic Church in France]] * [[Jean-Barthélemy Hauréau]]
== References ==
<references/> * [[Dreux du Radier]], ''Bibliothèque historique et critique du Poitou'' (Paris, 1754) * ''Gallia Christiana'', Vol. IV, Préface * ''Gallia Christiana (novissima)'' (Montbéliard, 1899), Préface to the Aix volume * [[de Longuemare]], ''Une famille d'auteurs aux seizième, dix-septième et dix-huitième siècles; les Sainte-Marthe'' (Paris, 1902) * Victor Fouque, ''Du "Gallia christiana" et de ses auteurs: étude bibliographique'', Paris: E. Tross, 1857. Available on the Bibliothèque nationale's [http://gallica.bnf.fr/Catalogue/noticesInd/FRBNF30453708.htm ''Gallica''] site.
== External links == * {{CathEncy|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/06350c.htm|title=Gallia Christiana}}
{{Catholic|wstitle=Gallia Christiana}}

/* Ilunga as a family name */
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=November 2010}}
'''Ilunga''' is a relatively common [[personal name]] in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]].
In June 2004, "ilunga" was reported as being a [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] word meaning "a person who is ready to forgive any abuse for the first time, to tolerate it a second time, but never a third time", and - in the opinion of 1,000 [[linguists]] surveyed on the subject – the [[world]]'s most [[Words hardest to translate|difficult word to translate]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3830521.stm BBC News: Congo word "most untranslatable"]</ref>
==Ilunga as a family name== Ilunga is a [[family name]] placed before the [[given name]]. There are many famous African and African-descended people named Ilunga. For example:
* [[Kalala Ilunga]], legendary founder of the [[Kingdom of Luba|Luba]] ethnic group of [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] * [[Bendele Ilunga]], [[Boxing|boxer]], [[Belgium]] * [[Didier Ilunga-Mbenga]], [[basketball]], Congo, joined [[Dallas Mavericks]] in July 2004 * [[Dorah Ilunga |Dorah Ilunga Kabulu]], [[politician]], Belgium * [[Enock Ilunga]], [[Painting|painter]], [[Zambia]] * [[Hérita Ilunga]], [[soccer|footballer]], [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] * [[Ferousi Ilunga]], boxer, Congo * [[Ilunga A. Kalonzo Ilunga]], politician, [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]] * [[Ilunga Katele]], traditional culture hero, royal ancestor of the [[Chokwe people|Chokwe]] people * [[Martin-Léonard Bakole wa Ilunga]] (deceased), [[Catholic]] [[archbishop]], Congo * [[Masengo Ilunga]], former footballer of [[Ethnikos Piraeus F.C.|Ethnikos Piraeus]] born in Zaire. * Gen. [[Ilunga Shamanga]] (deceased), [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], Army General, last interior minister of [[Mobutu]]'s regime, and later prominent member of the [[Congolese Rally for Democracy]] rebel group. * [[Ilunga Mwepu]], Congolese footballer * [[Kasongo Ilunga]], Congolese politician
Tshiluba is a language spoken in southeastern [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]].
==See also== * [[Words hardest to translate]]
==References== {{reflist}} * MacIntyre, Ben. ''Why do Koreans say "a biscuit would be nice" instead of "I want a biscuit"?'', [[The Times]], August 21, 2004.
[[Category:Language comparison]] [[Category:Given names]]

[[File:Acta independecia de Panamá 1821.jpg|thumb|Acta independecia de Panamá 1821]] The '''Declaration of Independence of Panama''' (Acta de Independencia de Panamá) is the document through which Panama declared its independence from the Spanish Empire on 28 November 1821. It was proclaimed in the Cathedral plaza of [[Panama City]] after a council of leaders had met and drafted twelve points calling for severing Panama's relationship with the Spanish Crown and joining with the newly formed [[Republic of Gran Colombia]].
==Background== {{main|Independence of Panama from Spain}}
After rebels in the small provincial town of [[Villa de los Santos]] issued the "Primer ''Grito de Independencia de la Villa de Los Santos''" (Shout for Independence),<ref name="Navarro (2014)">{{cite news|last1=Navarro|first1=Dayana|title=El Primer Grito de Independencia|url=http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/nacional/grito-independencia/23819615|accessdate=21 May 2015|publisher=La Estrella de Panamá|date=10 November 2014|location=Panama|language=Spanish}}</ref> on 10 November 1821, rebels throughout the Panamanian countryside began demanding independence. Using bribes to quell resistance from the Spanish troops and garner their desertion, the rebels gained control of [[Panama City]] without bloodshed.<ref name="McGuinness (2007)">{{cite book|last1=McGuinness|first1=Aims|title=Path of Empire: Panama and the California Gold Rush|date=2007|publisher=Cornell University Press|location=Ithaca, N.Y.|isbn=978-0-8014-4521-7|page=19|edition=1. publ.|url=https://books.google.com.mx/books?id=b-ECpNQ66V4C&lpg=PA19&dq}}</ref> An open meeting was held with merchants, landowners, and elites, who fearing retaliation from Spain and interruption of trade decided to join the [[Republic of Gran Colombia]] and drafted the Independence Act of Panama.<ref name="Martínez Garnica (2007)">{{cite journal|last1=Martínez Garnica|first1=Armando|last2=Quintero Montiel|first2=Inés|title=Actas de Declaración de Independencia|journal=Actas de formación de juntas y declaraciones de independencia (1809-1822)|date=2007|url=http://admonpublica.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/1821_11_28_Actas_Declaraci%C3%B3n_Independencia_Ciudad_de_Panam%C3%A1.pdf|publisher=Reales Audiencias de Quito, Caracas y Santa Fe|language=Spanish}}</ref>
==The "Declaration"== The Declaration of Independence was drafted on 28 November 1821 by the educator and diplomat [[Manuel José Hurtado]]<ref name="Díaz Villa (1998)">{{cite web|last1=Díaz Villa|first1=Tomás Ernesto|title=November 28, 1821|url=http://portal.critica.com.pa/archivo/112898/opi1.html|website=Critica|publisher=Critica|accessdate=21 May 2015|location=Panama City, Panama|language=Spanish|date=1998}}</ref> and consisted of twelve articles. The text is as follows:
:"In a general meeting of all civilian, military and ecclesiastical corporations held today 28 November 1821 at the invitation of the City Council, after more arrested discussions before a large village meeting and under the highest order and harmony were agreed and decreed by common agreement the following items:
#Panama, spontaneously and under the general vote of the people of understanding, is declared free and independent of the Spanish government. #The territory of the provinces of the Isthmus belongs to the ''Republic of Gran Colombia'', to whose Congress our deputy will promptly go to represent us. #Individuals of the troops garrisoned in this place have the absolute freedom to make the choice that suits them, and if they want to return to Spain, they will be provided all the necessary aid for transport to the island of Cuba; in keeping with the honors of war, those that will remain at the ports of Chagres or Portobelo, then shall make the garrisons the possessions of the new government; putting under obligation all the officers, sergeants and soldiers, under due oath, to remain calm, to not accept any bribes, nor to take up weapons against the independent states of America during the present war. #Spanish patients who are in hospital will be assisted by the government, and once they return to health will presented with the necessary assistance in accordance with Article 3. #The Head of State of the Isthmus is stated to be Don José de Fábrega, who was colonel with the Spanish armies; all corporations and authorities, civil and ecclesiastical shall be on the same footing that they are currently. #The Head of State shall take all economic measures that may be necessary for the preservation of the public peace. #The authorities will give at once the oath of independence, distinguishing next Sunday for its publication with the due solemnity. #The Head of State, together with the commanders of the troops, will notify the fortress of Chagres and detachment of Portobelo so that the official who presents the orders delivers these points in military style. #The Isthmus, by means of its representatives, will form the suitable economic regulations for its internal government; and in the meantime they will govern according to the current laws in those parts that do not contradict the current state. #For necessary expenses, the political Head of State will create a loan to be recognized as part of the public debt. #The public debt is recognized by the Treasury and shall be paid under the covenants set forth in its principle. #The preceding chapters will be printed and circulated to all the peoples of the Isthmus to cease the disagreements agitating them; sending the help that this capital needs to carry out this glorious undertaking, as they have offered.
::Signed by: [[José de Fábrega]]; [[José Hijinio]], bishop of Panama; [[Juan José Martínez]] (dean of the cathedral chapter); Dr. [[Carlos Icaza]]; [[Manuel José Calvo]]; [[Mariano de Arosemena]]; [[Luis Lasso de la Vega]]; [[José Antonio Cerda]]; [[Juan Herrera y Torres]]; [[Juan José Calvo]]; [[Narciso de Urriola]]; [[Remigio Lasso de la Vega]]; [[Manuel de Arce]]; [[José de Alba]]; [[Gregorio Gómez]]; [[Luis Salvador Durán]]; [[José María Herrera]]; [[Manuel María de Ayala]]; [[Víctor Beltrán]]; [[Antonio Bermejo]]; [[Antonio Plana]]; [[Juan Pío Victoria]]; Dr. [[Manuel de Urriola]]; [[José Vallarino]]; [[Manuel José Hurtado]], [[Manuel García de Paredes]]; Dr. [[Manuel José de Arce]]; [[José María Calvo]]; [[Antonio Escovar]]; [[Gaspar Arosemena]] [[José de los Santos Correoso]], public scribe.<ref name="Martínez Garnica (2007)">{{cite journal|last1=Martínez Garnica|first1=Armando|last2=Quintero Montiel|first2=Inés|title=Actas de Declaración de Independencia|journal=Actas de formación de juntas y declaraciones de independencia (1809-1822)|date=2007|url=http://admonpublica.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/1821_11_28_Actas_Declaraci%C3%B3n_Independencia_Ciudad_de_Panam%C3%A1.pdf|publisher=Reales Audiencias de Quito, Caracas y Santa Fe|language=Spanish}}</ref>
[[José Vallarino Jiménez]] was chosen to inform the people gathered in the Cathedral Plaza of Panama City of the Declaration of Independence. The news was received with jubilation. A letter advising [[Simón Bolívar]] of the declaration and Panama's voluntary decision to join with [[Republic of Gran Colombia]] was sent. In his acknowledgement, dated 1 February 1822, Bolívar replied:<ref name="Díaz Villa (1998)" />
{{cquote|''El Acta de Independencia de Panamá es el monumento más glorioso que pueda ofrecer a la Historia ninguna provincia americana. Todo está allí consultado: justicia, generosidad, política e interés nacional.'' (The Decaration of Independence of Panama is the most glorious monument that could be offered to the History of any American province. Everything has been considered: justice, generosity, politics and national interest.)|20px|20px|- Simón Bolívar to José de Fábrega (1 February 1822)<ref name="Díaz Villa (1998)" />}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
